meta.name: generator
meta.content: HTML Tidy for Windows (vers 14 February 2006), see www.w3.org

div.p: Plugin Version @PLUGIN_VERSION@

WebLogic is a server software application that runs on a middle tier, between back-end databases and related applications and browser-based thin clients. The main features of WebLogic server include connectors that make it possible for any legacy application on any client to interoperate with server applications, Enterprise JavaBean (EJB) components, resource pooling, and connection sharing that make applications very scalable. An administration console with a user interface makes management tasks more efficient and features such as Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) support for the encryption of data transmissions, as well as authentication and authorization mechanisms, make applications and secure.

This plugin allows users to interact with the Oracle WebLogic server. The plugin usage is focused on application and server status management, being able of interacting or editing existing application, and deploying new ones. The Managed Servers and the Admin Server can be both started and stopped at any moment with this integration. Jython scripting is allowed providing the script file or by entering a new embedded file when required.
This plugin was developed and tested against WebLogic version 10.3.
IMPORTANT: For all parameter descriptions below, required parameters are shown in bold italics.

Plugin configurations are sets of parameters that apply across some or all of the plugin's procedures. They are intended to reduce repetition of common values, create predefined sets of parameters for end users, and to securely store credentials where needed. Each configuration is given a unique name that is entered in designated parameters on procedures that use them.
Plugin configurations are created by going to the Electric Commander "Administration" tab, then to the "Defect Tracking" sub-tab.
To enable Commander to communicate with your WebLogic Application Server, create a WebLogic configuration, supplying the following information:

tr.td: Identifier of the configuration to create. This parameter is required. (Required)
Url of a WebLogic Server (must include protocol, server and port). (Required)

Username: Provide the user name Commander uses to communicate with the WebLogic server.
Password: Provide the password for the specified Username.
Retype Password: Retype the password specified.

div.p: Note: in the URL the protocol is "t3", this is because RMI communications in WebLogic Server use the "t3" protocol to transport data between WebLogic Server and other Java programs, including clients and other WebLogic Server instances. A server instance keeps track of each Java Virtual Machine (JVM) with which it connects, and creates a single "t3" connection to carry all traffic for a JVM. This proctocol is used in most of the procedures of the WebLogic Plugin
Deploys or redeploys an application or module using the weblogic. Deployer provided java class.

tr.td: Absolute path of java. i.e: "java", "java.exe" or "/path/to/java". (Required)
Deployment name to assign to a newly-deployed application or standalone module. (Required)
Absolute path of the application to deploy. i.e: "/path/to/webapp.war" or "c:/mydir/webapp.war". (Required)
Name of the configuration to be used for retrieving Admin Server's URL and credentials.
Targets on which to deploy the application or module (comma-separated list of the target servers, clusters, or virtual hosts).
Additional commands to be entered for weblogic.Deployer.
Absolute path of the setDomainEnv script, including filename and extension. i.e: "/path/to/setDomainEnv.sh" or "setDomainEnv.cmd".

Absolute path of the weblogic jar, needed to run the deploy function. In Windows environment, if the jar is already added to the enviroment classpath variable, then is not necesary to include it. In Linux environment you must include the path. i.e: "/path/to/weblogic.jar" or "/root/Oracle/Middleware/wlserver_10.3/server/lib/weblogic.jar".

div.p: To deploy an application, select the following highlighted step:
Then, enter the following parameters:
When the job is executed, you should see the following job detail, note the output indicating the application was deployed successfully:
In the DeployApp step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report:
Stops the deployment unit and removes staged files from target servers.

tr.td: Absolute path of java. i.e: "java", "java.exe" or "/path/to/java". (Required)
Name of the application to undeploy. i.e: "webapp". (Required)
Enables stopping the application in Graceful Mode (after existing HTTP clients have completed their work).
Name of the configuration to be used for retrieving Admin Server's URL and credentials.
Additional commands to be entered for weblogic.Deployer.
Absolute path of the setDomainEnv script, including filename and extension. i.e: "/path/to/setDomainEnv.sh" or "setDomainEnv.cmd".

Absolute path of the weblogic jar, needed to run the undeploy function. In Windows environment, if the jar is already added to the enviroment classpath variable, then is not necesary to include it. In Linux environment you must include the path. i.e: "/path/to/weblogic.jar" or "/root/Oracle/Middleware/wlserver_10.3/server/lib/weblogic.jar".

In the UndeployApp step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report:

tr.td: Absolute path of java. i.e: "java", "java.exe" or "/path/to/java". (Required)
Name of the application to start. i.e: "webapp". (Required)
Name of the configuration to be used for retrieving Admin Server's URL and credentials.
Additional commands to be entered for weblogic.Deployer.
Absolute path of the setDomainEnv script, including filename and extension. i.e: "/path/to/setDomainEnv.sh" or "setDomainEnv.cmd".

Absolute path of the weblogic jar, needed to run the start application function. In Windows environment, if the jar is already added to the enviroment classpath variable, then is not necesary to include it. In Linux environment you must include the path. i.e: "/path/to/weblogic.jar" or "/root/Oracle/Middleware/wlserver_10.3/server/lib/weblogic.jar".

div.p: To start an application, select the following highlighted step:
Then, enter the following parameters:

In the StartApp step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report:

tr.td: Absolute path of java. i.e: "java", "java.exe" or "/path/to/java". (Required)
Name of the application to stop. i.e: "webapp". (Required)
Enables stopping the application in Graceful Mode (after existing HTTP clients have completed their work).
Name of the configuration to be used for retrieving Admin Server's URL and credentials.
Additional commands to be entered for weblogic.Deployer.
Absolute path of the setDomainEnv script, including filename and extension. i.e: "/path/to/setDomainEnv.sh" or "setDomainEnv.cmd".

Absolute path of the weblogic jar, needed to run the stop application function. In Windows environment, if the jar is already added to the enviroment classpath variable, then is not necesary to include it. In Linux environment you must include the path. i.e: "/path/to/weblogic.jar" or "/root/Oracle/Middleware/wlserver_10.3/server/lib/weblogic.jar".

div.p: To stop an application, select the following highlighted step:
Then, enter the following parameters:
When the job is executed, you should see the following job detail, note the output indicating the application was stoped successfully:
In the StopApp step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report:
Runs weblogic.Deployer in a free-mode. Weblogic.Deployer is a Java-based deployment tool that provides a command-line interface to the WebLogic Server deployment API.

tr.td: The weblogic.Deployer command to use. i.e: "-deploy", "-undeploy", "-stop" or "-listapps". (Required)
Name of the configuration to be used for retrieving Admin Server's URL and credentials.
Additional commands to be entered for weblogic.Deployer.
Absolute path of java. i.e: "java", "java.exe" or "/path/to/java". (Required)
Name of the application to manage. i.e: "webapp". (Required)
Absolute path of the setDomainEnv script, including filename and extension. i.e: "/path/to/setDomainEnv.sh" or "setDomainEnv.cmd".

Absolute path of the weblogic jar, needed to run the weblogic.Deployer in a free-mode. In Windows environment, if the jar is already added to the enviroment classpath variable, then is not necesary to include it. In Linux environment you must include the path. i.e: "/path/to/weblogic.jar" or "/root/Oracle/Middleware/wlserver_10.3/server/lib/weblogic.jar".

div.p: To run the weblogic.Deployer in a free-mode, select the following highlighted step:
Then, enter the following parameters:
When the job is executed, you should see the following job detail, note the output indicating the job ran successfully:
In the RunJob step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report:

Runs Jython scripts using weblogic.WLST. The WebLogic Scripting Tool (WLST) is a command-line scripting interface that system administrators and operators use to monitor and manage WebLogic Server instances and domains. The WLST scripting environment is based on the Java scripting interpreter, Jython. In addition to WebLogic scripting functions, you can use common features of interpreted languages, including local variables, conditional variables, and flow control statements.

tr.td: Absolute path to WLST. i.e: "/path/to/wlst.cmd" or "wlst.sh". (Required)
Absolute path of a Jython script containing the desired job. The path is used only if "Supplied File" is selected in the "Script File Source" parameter. i.e: "/path/to/scriptfile.jython".
Indicates the source of the script file to execute. Either a existent file in the path defined in the 'scriptfile' parameter OR a new one using the code specified in scriptfile parameter. (Required)
Content of the script file to run if "New Script File" option is chosen in the "Script File Source" parameter.
Additional commands to be entered for weblogic.WLST.

Absolute path of the weblogic jar, needed to run Jython scripts using weblogic.WLST. In Windows environment, if the jar is already added to the enviroment classpath variable, then is not necesary to include it. In Linux environment you must include the path. i.e: "/path/to/weblogic.jar" or "/root/Oracle/Middleware/wlserver_10.3/server/lib/weblogic.jar".

div.p: To see a complete example, see the Examples and Use Cases section.
Starts the WebLogic Admin Server

tr.td: Absolute path of the startWeblogic script, including filename and extension. i.e: "/path/to/startWeblogic.cmd". (Required)
Instance name of the Admin Server to start. i.e: "AdminServer". (Required)
Configuration name from which the Admin URL and credentials will be read. (Required)
Absolute path to WLST. i.e: "/path/to/wlst.cmd" or "wlst.sh". (Required)

Defines the maximum time in seconds that the job will try to check into the server. Note that the step has a "Time Limit" property, so if this property is set to less than the parameter it will abort the step early. Blank implies no wait time (URL only checked one time).

div.p: To start the administration server, select the following highlighted step:
Then, enter the following parameters:

When the job is executed, you should see the following job detail, note the output indicating the server was started successfully (the warning indicates that the server is been accessed by an insecure protocol):
In the StartAdminServer step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report:

Starts a WebLogic Managed Server. A WebLogic Server administration domain is a logically related group of WebLogic Server resources. Usually, you configure a domain to include additional WebLogic Server instances called Managed Servers. You deploy Web applications, EJBs, and other resources onto the Managed Servers and use the Administration Server for configuration and management purposes only. Note that the Node Manager must be running before run this procedure.

In order to start the managed server, a file called "boot.properties" must be created in the path "$DOMAIN_DIR$/servers/myserver/security", and this file must have the credentials needed to start the server. i.e:
username=weblogic
password=w3blogic

tr.td: Absolute path of the start server script, including filename and extension. i.e: "/path/to/startManagedServer.cmd". (Required)
Instance name of the Managed Server to start. (Required)
Configuration name from which the Managed Server URL and the credentials from the Admin Server will be read. (Required)
URL from the Admin Server (including protocol and port). (Required)
Absolute path to WLST. i.e: "/path/to/wlst.cmd" or "wlst.sh". (Required)

Defines the maximum time in seconds that the job will try to check into the server. Note that the step has a "Time Limit" property, so if this property is set to less than the parameter it will abort the step early. Blank implies no wait time (URL only checked one time).

div.p: To start a managed server, select the following highlighted step:
Then, enter the following parameters:

When the job is executed, you should see the following job detail, note the output indicating the server was started successfully (the warning indicates that the server is been accessed by an insecure protocol):
In the StartInstance step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report:
Stops a WebLogic Managed Server. Note that the Node Manager must be running before run this procedure.

tr.td: Absolute path of the stop server script, including filename and extension. i.e: "/path/to/stopManagedServer.cmd". (Required)
Instance name of the Managed Server to stop. (Required)
Configuration name from which the URL is retrieved. (Required)

div.p: To stop the admin server, select the following highlighted step:
Then, enter the following parameters:

When the job is executed, you should see the following job detail, note the output indicating the job ran successfully (the warning indicates that the server is been accessed by an insecure protocol):
In the StopAdminServer step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report:
Stops a WebLogic Admin Server

tr.td: Absolute path of the stopWeblogic script, including filename and extension. i.e: "/path/to/stopWeblogic.cmd". (Required)
Configuration name from which the URL and credentials are retrieved. (Required)

div.p: To stop the admin server, select the following highlighted step:
Then, enter the following parameters:

When the job is executed, you should see the following job detail, note the output indicating the job ran successfully (the warning indicates that the server is been accessed by an insecure protocol):
In the StopAdminServer step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report:
Check the status of the given server URL.

tr.td: Name of the configuration to be used. URL, port and credentials are gathered from the given configuration.
Absolute path to WLST. i.e: "/path/to/wlst.cmd" or"wlst.sh". (Required)
Defines the maximum time in seconds that the job will try to check into the server. Blank implies no wait time (URL only checked one time).
Indicates the expected correct result to be obtained when running checking the server. (Required)
Indicates the name of the instance to be checked. (Required)

div.p: To stop the admin server, select the following highlighted step:
Then, enter the following parameters:

When the job is executed, you should see the following job detail, note the output indicating the job ran successfully (the warning indicates that the server is been accessed by an insecure protocol):
In the StopAdminServer step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report:
Check the status of the given page URL.

tr.td: The credentials needed to check the status of the page.
Defines the maximum time in seconds that the job will try to check into the server. Blank implies no wait time (URL only checked one time).
URL of the page to be checked. (Required)
Indicates the expected correct result to be obtained when running checking the server.

div.p: To stop the admin server, select the following highlighted step:
Then, enter the following parameters:
When the job is executed, you should see the following job detail, note the output indicating the job ran successfully:
In the StopAdminServer step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report:

Note: in the URL the protocol is "http", this is because for this procedure, the Electric Commander use an internal method to test the status of the URL pages with the original "http" protocol used in the web browsers.

Starts the WebLogic Node Manager. Node Manager is a WebLogic Server utility that enables you to start, shut down, and restart Administration Server and Managed Server instances from a remote location. Although Node Manager is optional, it is recommended if your WebLogic Server environment hosts applications with high availability requirements.

tr.td: Absolute path of the startNodeManager script, including filename and extension. i.e: '/Oracle/Middleware/wlserver_10.3/server/bin/startNodeManager.cmd'. (Required)

Defines the time in seconds that the job wait to test the status of the node manager. Note that the step has a "Time Limit" property, so if this property is set to less than the parameter it will abort the step early. Blank implies no wait time (URL only checked one time).

div.p: To start the node manager, select the following highlighted step:
Then, enter the following parameters:
When the job is executed, you should see the following job detail, note the output indicating the node manager was started successfully:
In the CheckNodeManagerStatus step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report:
Stops the WebLogic Node Manager.

tr.td: Configuration name from which the credentials will be read. (Required)
Host name of Node Manager. This argument defaults to localhost.

Port number of Node Manager. This argument defaults to a value that is based on the Node Manager server type, for plain type, defaults to 5556. For rsh type, defaults to 514. For ssh type, defaults to 22. For ssl type, defaults to 5556.
Name of the domain that you want to manage. This argument defaults to mydomain.

Path of the domain directory to which you want to save the Node Manager secret file (nm_password.properties) and SerializedSystemIni.dat file. This argument defaults to the directory in which WLST was started.
Absolute path to WLST. i.e: '/path/to/wlst.cmd' or 'wlst.sh'. (Required)
Type of the Node Manager server. This argument defaults to ssl.

Defines the time in seconds that the job wait to test the status of the node manager. Note that the step has a "Time Limit" property, so if this property is set to less than the parameter it will abort the step early. Blank implies no wait time (URL only checked one time).

div.p: To stop the node manager, select the following highlighted step:
Then, enter the following parameters:
When the job is executed, you should see the following job detail, note the output indicating the node manager was stopped successfully:
In the CheckNodeManagerStatus step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report:

In this example, the objetive is to print an 'Hello World!' in the output using the Supplied File option with an existing scrit file in a path, and using the New Script File option with embedded code.
To run the custom job, select the following highlighted step:
Then, enter the following parameters. The first image is for the Supplied File option, and the second one is for New Script File:
When the job is executed, you should see the following job detail, note the output indicating the successfully execution, this applies for both Script File Source options:
In the RunWLST step, click the Log icon to see the log info. This applies both Script File Source option, the output is similar to the following sample:
The next image shows the HelloWorld.jython file used in the Supplied File option:

ul.li: Added a parameter in the start and stop server procedures to determine the maximun time in seconds to test the status of the server.
Created 2 new procedures: StartNodeManager and StopNodeManager.
Upgrade to use the new Parameter Form XML.
Added a link directly to the new help document.
New Parameter Panels for each procedure
Added weblogic jar Absolute Path param into the DeployApp, UndeployApp, StartApp, StopApp, RunDeployer and RunWLST method, needed in Linux environment to load WebLogic libreries.
Added adminserverurl param into the StartManagedServer method.
Modified the CheckServerProcedure procedure, CURL is not needed and parameters were changed
Fixed minor bug on Configuration List page.
Procedures have one step only and are executed using Perl directly
Credentials in the StartManagedServer procedure must be stored in a boot.properties file
